lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/duke.Jamie.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run duke.Jamie.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
* Deadline class which inherits from the Task class.
* @param item Item that has a deadline.
* @param by The date that the item is due by.
* Exception class that handles exceptions specific to the Jamie class.
* Event class which inherits from the Task class.
* @param item The item that would be happening.
* @param at The date that the item is at.
* Jamie is an assistant that helps keep track of deadlines, events and todos.
* The constructor that creates a Jamie object.
* @param filePath FilePath where the data stored by Jamie is located.
* JamieTime class converts DateTime inputs and outputs.
* Formats the dateTime String from user or file input.
* @param input Date and time in the format d/M/yyyy HHmm.
* @return Date and time for users to read with ease.
* Undo the formatting done to a date and time input.
* @param input Date and time in the format read by users.
* @return Date and time format to be stored in a text file.
* The class that deals with user commands.
* Starts the parser object and carry out the user commands.
* The class that deals with loading and saving tasks in the file.
* The method which loads the file.
* @return The list of tasks that were stored in the file.
System.out.println("Error in locating/creating the save file");
* Saves the tasks into a text file.
* @param tasks The tasks that are being saved.
* Task class that creates a task inputted by user.
* The constructor of the Task class.
* @param item The item that the task contains.
* Returns the task in a String that can be recognised by the text file.
* @return A string that can can be recognised by the text file.
* Checks if the task contains the keyword.
* @param keyWord The keyword that is being checked.
* @return True if the task contains the keyword, false otherwise.
* The class that represents the list of tasks inputted by the user.
* The constructor of the TaskList class.
* Gets the size of the task list.
* Gets the task from the task list with the given index.
* @param index Index of the task wanted.
* Add a task into the task list.
* @param task The task that is being added.
* Deletes a task from the task list.
* @param num The number of the task that is being deleted.
public Task deleteTask(int num) throws DukeException {
* @param number The number of the task that is being marked.
public void mark(int number) throws DukeException {
* Marks the task as not done.
* @param number The number of the task that is being unmarked.
public void unMark(int number) throws DukeException {
* Converts the taskList to a string that can be inputted into the text file.
* Returns a list of tasks that contains the keyword.
* @param keyWord Keyword that is being searched for.
* @return A taskList containing tasks that contains the keyword.
* @throws DukeException If the new taskList is empty.
public TaskList find(String keyWord) throws DukeException {
* ToDo class which inherits from the Task class.
* The class with deals with user interaction.
* Prints a welcome message when the program starts.
System.out.println("Hi, I'm Jamie.\nWhat do you want to do?\n"
+ "For dates and time, please enter in the format:\n"
* The method to list out the tasks that are present in taskList.
* Prints out the message when a task is added.
* @param task The task that is added.
System.out.println("Got it! I've added this task:\n  "
* Prints out the message for when a task is being marked.
* @param marking The marking that is being done.
* @param task The task that is being marked.
public void markingUi(String marking, Task task) {
System.out.println("Ok! I've marked it as done.\n  "
System.out.println("Ok! I've marked it as undone.\n  "
* Prints out the message for when a task is deleted.
* @param task The task that is deleted.
* Prints out the message that displays the number of tasks in the list of tasks.
System.out.println("You now have " + tasks.size() + " tasks in the list :)");
* Prints out an error message when there are missing numbers.
* @param command The command that was called.
* Prints out an error message when an invalid command is called.
* Prints out an error message when something is missing in the description of a task.
* @param task The task that has a missing description.
System.out.println("Something is missing in the description of this + " + task + "! >:(");
* The error message for when there is no such task.
* Prints a bye message when the program ends.
The description of todo cannot be empty >:(
Got it! I've added this task:
Now you have 1 tasks in the list :)
Something is missing in the description of this deadline >:(

Got it! I've added this task:
Now you have 2 tasks in the list :)
Got it! I've added this task:
Now you have 3 tasks in the list :)
Something is missing in the description of this event >:(
Got it! I've added this task:

Ok! I've marked it as done.
Ok! I've marked it as done.
Ok! I've marked it as undone.
Now you have 3 tasks in the list :)
